results.title: Ping Pong
results.brief_description: An experimental abstract film. Animated sketches form and dissolve to background of music by percussion instruments. Stick figures and leg outlines glide and dance, flit and disintegrate into hail, through which a little girl wends with her umbrella. Occasionally the lively lines weaves into shapes that suggest the background of cymbals and drums.

results.title: Ping pong
results.brief_description: The National Film Board of Canada filmed the table tennis competition between teams of young Canadians and Chinese that took place in the People’s Republic of China in the summer of 1973, the first time in twenty-five years that such filming was made possible. Shown are highlights of play at the China-Canada Friendship Meet, as well as some of the sightseeing taken in by the young Canadians - a visit, for example, to the Great Wall of China. A film without commentary.

results.title: Pine ways to profit
results.brief_description: The pine farmers in the South are learning to protect their forest as another source of income. The wood is used as chips, pulp, turpentine, poles, posts and stumps. They are at most risk from fire and prevention and cooperation between fire preventers and neighbours is essential. Methods of prevention and protection for seedlings are shown.

results.title: Pine Gap images
results.brief_description: A celebrations of documented images of the women’s protest camp at Pine Gap, Australian Northern Territory in November 1983. A series of images representing the feeling of some of the women acting for qualitative change and for world peace. A discussion starter about non-violent protest action.

results.title: Pin up girl
results.creator_credit: William Le Baron, Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and Bruce Humberstone
results.brief_description: Gorgeous Betty Grable (voted the Armed Forces’ favourite pin up girl), stars as a War Department typist, who doubles as a small-time USO entertainer desperate for a chance at the big-time. Her penchant for telling lies gets her into all sorts of trouble especially when she fibs her way into the company of war hero Tommy Dooley (John Harvey) by pretending to be a musical star. Her life gets more complicated when she is appointed secretary to the handsome war hero. Barely disguised, she manages to fool him for a time, but not when she flashes those million dollar legs! Grable turns in a wonderful performance and there are several excellent musical numbers.
results.creator_credit_for_label: William Le Baron, Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and Bruce Humberstone

results.title: Pillow talk
results.creator_credit: Universal Pictures, Arwin Productions, Ross Hunter, Martin Melcher and Michael Gordon
results.brief_description: Doris Day is Jan Morrow, a single interior designer who has to share a telephone party-line with Brad Allen, a playboy musician played by Rock Hudson. His best-friend, millionaire Tony Randall, is in love with Jan. Brad thinks it would be fun to pretend to be someone else and see if he can woo Jan away from his friend. Things turn a little crazy, however, when he finds himself falling in love for the first time. The problem: Jan hates Brad. This crazy, funny love story is one of Hollywood’s camp classics, a delicious comedy about sex, virginity, and the games girls and boys play with each other. Though initially criticised as “superficial” by contemporary critics, in hindsight, the Hudson/Day romantic comedies still seem fresh in comparison to the “serious” Hollywood fare of its day. In part this comes from the playfulness with which Hudson and Day approach their roles, immersing themselves in their characters (she’s pure and virginal, he’s manly and a womaniser) at the same time investing enough subversive “queerness” in their roles to amuse those amongst us who may or may not be heterosexual. Features great songs, beautiful art direction and design, and a terrific supporting performance by Randall. Pure delight. Winner of an Academy Award for Best Screenplay.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Universal Pictures, Arwin Productions, Ross Hunter, Martin Melcher and Michael Gordon

results.title: Pilgrimage of the devil worshippers
results.brief_description: A Kurdistan/Australian co-production. Yazidi villagers go on a pilgrimage annually to the holy shrine of Scheikh-Adi. This film follows the pilgrimage to its destination hidden deep in the Kurdistan valley. Filmed by Georges Drion. Commentary by Rob Antill.

results.title: Pilgrimage
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Journey into the Himalayas”.
Keith Adam mounts an expedition to the source of India’s sacred river, the Ganges. Hundreds of thousands of devout Hindus make the gruelling journey from the hot, dusty plains of the Indian sub-continent to witness, for the first time in their lives, the terrifying grandeur of the Himalayan peaks which give birth to the holiest of all rivers.

results.title: Pilferage
results.brief_description: The problem of shoplifting in self-service stores. A grocer is seen trying various solutions. Points out that many legal technicalities are involved in direct accusation; that some means of dissuading shoplifters will also irritate good ccustomers; but continuous courtesy and helpfulness will drive away the bad customers while retaining the good.

results.title: Pile Ou Face = Heads or Tails
results.brief_description:
Edouard Morlaix’s wife dies after falling through a window. Inspector Baroni is convinced she was pushed by Morlaix who wanted to be free to run away with his mistress. Baroni starts harrassing Morlaix in the hope to have him break down and admit to the murder.

Credits: Producer, Georges Cravenne ; director, Robert Enrico ; writers, Robert Enrico, Michel Audiard, Marcel Jullian ; photography, Didier Tarot ; music, Lino Leonardi.
Cast: Philippe Noiret, Michel Serrault, Dorothee, Pierre Arditi, Andre Falcon, Fred Personne, Jean Desailly.
